questiontext.text:
Use base-10 logarithm tables to evaluate:

\[ {@a@} \times {@b@} \]

You must use base-10 logarithm tables.
Give your answer correct to three significant figures.

[[input:ans1]]
[[validation:ans1]]

generalfeedback.text:
Worked solution

We are asked to evaluate

\[ {@a@} \times {@b@} \]

using base-10 logarithm tables.

First, the logarithms of the two numbers are found using the tables:

  • \(\log_{10}({@a@}) \approx {@loga@}\)
  • \(\log_{10}({@b@}) \approx {@logb@}\)

Using the law of logarithms,

\[ \log(ab) = \log a + \log b, \]

we add the logarithms:

\[ \log_{10}({@a@} \times {@b@}) \approx {@logsum@}. \]

The next step is to find the antilogarithm. From the tables,

\[ {@a@} \times {@b@} \approx 10^{@logsum@}. \]

This gives a value close to the exact product. Rounding to three significant figures,

\[ {@a@} \times {@b@} \approx {@ta@}. \]

So the correct answer is {@ta@}.

questiondescription.text: Students must evaluate the product of two numbers using base-10 logarithm tables. The question is randomised and assessed using a Potential Response Tree to diagnose common errors in the use of logarithms.

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done.

truefeedback.text: Well done. Your answer is correct to three significant figures.

It appears that you added the two numbers instead of multiplying them.
Remember that logarithms are used to convert a multiplication into an addition of logarithms, not an addition of the original numbers.

It looks like you used only the mantissas from the logarithm tables.
Remember that when finding an antilogarithm, you must also include the characteristic, which determines the correct power of 10.

falsefeedback.text:
Your answer is not correct. Check that you have:
  • used base-10 logarithms,
  • added the logarithms correctly,
  • included the correct power of 10,
  • rounded your final answer appropriately.
